Summary Allison Garcia is a seasoned digital brand manager with 15 years experience in leading teams through full lifecycle product engagements from creating strategy and conducting research, to creating product specifications and delivering on the product vision. She has a passion for user experience and strives to improve any product experience through data driven enhancements.  
 
With experience on both the agency side and client side of the house, Allison has faced numerous unique project management scenarios that demanded decisiveness, empathy and adaptability. By leveraging this expertise along with her wide industry experience, she is a keystone addition to any company looking to build a successful product and delivery team. Her diverse background is also key in her ability to create mindful project processes that blend current and traditional methodologies with a focus on instilling a culture of sustainable project delivery and healthy team culture. 
 
High Level Industry and Project Experience: Localization of US Brands for International Audiences, Managing Distributed Teams, Delivering on Integrated and Transmedia Programs for Global Brands, Finance, Automotive, Entertainment, Television, Healthcare, Pharma, User Research, Digital Brand Management. B2B Integration Component Development Wipro, Internal Initiative for Ip (February 2001 – September 2001) 
•	Wipro B2Bi Components – This was an internal initiative to develop its own B2B integration component framework. It is based on loosely coupled document exchange using Internet Protocols with clearly defined service interfaces that allow organizations to integrate their Business Processes with that of their partners over the Internet. Organizations can integrate business processes like procurement, sales order processing, customer service, customer support, supply chain management etc. with their Business Partners over the Internet. The component framework manages message and document exchange between Business partners using Internet as medium to accomplish a defined Business Process. Configurable service interfaces, ability to specify and configure document types, message types, standard document vocabularies across organizations is the key differentiation of such a framework. The Business Process Modeling Framework was developed ground up starting with requirements gathering and management using Requisite Pro, Use Case Elaboration, UML modeling in Rational Rose, design using the J2EE framework. Managed a team of 25 people. 
•	Web Based system that uses 3-tier architecture (HTML, NAS, Java, Oracle Database). Used Rational Rose for design, SVF for reporting, MS Project for planning 
 
B2B Integration Component Development Wipro, Internal Initiative for Ip (February 2001 – September 2001) 
•	Wipro B2Bi Components – This was an internal initiative to develop its own B2B integration component framework. It is based on loosely coupled document exchange using Internet Protocols with clearly defined service interfaces that allow organizations to integrate their Business Processes with that of their partners over the Internet. Organizations can integrate business processes like procurement, sales order processing, customer service, customer support, supply chain management etc. with their Business Partners over the Internet. The component framework manages message and document exchange between Business partners using Internet as medium to accomplish a defined Business Process. Configurable service interfaces, ability to specify and configure document types, message types, standard document vocabularies across organizations is the key differentiation of such a framework. Summary Do what Yahoo!, my current employer, does: Give me the most complicated, challenging, and large-scale technology projects you have. That's where I excel. 
 
As a respected change-agent at Yahoo! known to have one of the largest technology infrastructures on the planet, I've made name for myself as someone who can manage extremely complex projects and retain top talent. 
 
Some recent large-scale projects I've led for Yahoo! include the following. 
 
--Global IPv6 Flag Day trials 
--Post-acquisition technology integrations (~60 M&As, 30+ in 2013 alone) 
--Outsourcing and offshoring programs in EMEA and APAC 
--Reporting solutions for 20+ Fortune 50 companies 
--Open-source platform builds in cahoots with Apple 
--Enterprise-level consolidation of IT into Operations 
--Server provisioning during the 3 biggest Internet events ever 
 
I've assembled and managed leadership teams of up to 20 engineers and project managers to drive high-profile initiatives. My staff tend to stick around, even during the tough periods, because they can see my passion for what I do. That, and I make sure they're working on technologies that blow their hair back.
